title: Screen Reader Support - Diluter
description: Your company is launching a new interface without proper screen reader support. The manager minimizes concerns and distracts with other priorities.

step_1.text: We're launching this new interface next month. It's going to be great - clean, fast, really intuitive. The users are going to love it.

user_choices.choice: That sounds great! I'm excited to see the new interface.
What about screen reader compatibility?
How does it work for people with visual impairments?
Have we done any testing with assistive technology?

step_2a.text: Right? It's going to be so much better than what we have now. No more cluttered interfaces or confusing navigation. Just clean, simple design that gets the job done.

user_choices.choice: Clean and simple sounds perfect.
Simple is good, but we need to make sure it's still accessible.
What did we remove to make it simpler?
I hope we didn't sacrifice functionality for simplicity.

step_2b.text: Oh that? Yeah, we've got that covered. It's all built into the browser stuff now anyway. Modern browsers handle all that automatically.

user_choices.choice: If browsers handle it automatically, that should work.
Browsers need proper markup to work with screen readers.
Have we actually tested it with screen readers?
Browser support varies - we should verify this works.

step_2c.text: Look, honestly, most of our users don't have visual impairments. We're talking about maybe 1-2% of our user base. We can't optimize for every edge case.

user_choices.choice: You're right, we can't optimize for every edge case.
1-2% is still thousands of real people.
Those aren't edge cases - they're our users too.
We have legal obligations regardless of percentages.

step_2d.text: Testing? Come on, we're not building rocket ships here. It's a web interface - if it works in Chrome, it works everywhere. Don't overthink it.

user_choices.choice: You're right, I might be overthinking this.
Assistive technology is different from just browser compatibility.
Some testing would help us avoid problems later.
This could affect real users - it's worth the extra effort.

step_3a.text: Exactly! Users want things that just work. They don't care about all the technical stuff behind the scenes as long as it's fast and easy to use.

user_choices.choice: You're right, users just want things that work.
But some users need specific technical features to make it work.
Fast and easy should include everyone, not just some users.
How do we know it works for users with disabilities?

step_3b.text: Look, accessible doesn't have to mean complicated. The interface is clean and simple - that's accessible right there. Less clutter means less confusion.

user_choices.choice: Clean and simple is definitely more accessible.
Simple for some users might be unusable for others.
We should verify that simple actually works for screen readers.
Less clutter is good, but we need proper labels and structure.

step_3c.text: Nothing major - just cleaned up some redundant buttons and streamlined the navigation. Got rid of all those extra options that nobody was using anyway.

user_choices.choice: Removing unused options sounds like good UX.
How do we know nobody was using those options?
Some of those options might have been important for assistive technology.
Streamlined navigation needs to stay navigable for everyone.

step_3d.text: Nah, we didn't sacrifice anything important. Just cleaned up the interface to focus on what actually matters. Sometimes less is more, you know?

user_choices.choice: You're right, sometimes less is more.
What matters to one user might be different for another.
Can we review what was removed to make sure it wasn't needed?
Less should still include basic features for all users.

step_3e.text: See? That's what I'm talking about. The browser companies have done all the heavy lifting for us. We don't need to reinvent the wheel here.

user_choices.choice: If browsers handle it, that should be sufficient.
Browser support still requires proper markup from our end.
We should test to make sure the browser support actually works.
Even with browser support, we need to verify the user experience.

step_3f.text: Yeah, but that's all standard HTML stuff. Our developers know how to write proper markup - it's not like we're doing anything fancy here.

user_choices.choice: Standard HTML should cover the basics.
Can we review the markup to ensure it's properly structured?
Standard HTML still needs testing with actual screen readers.
Proper markup is good, but we need to verify the user experience.

step_3g.text: Come on, do we really need to test every little thing? It's a pretty standard interface. If it works for regular users, it'll work fine for screen readers too.

user_choices.choice: You're right, standard interfaces should work fine.
Screen readers interact differently than regular browsers.
A quick test could save us from problems later.
We should make sure it actually works for the people who need it.

step_3h.text: Browser support is pretty consistent these days. And honestly, if someone's using some weird old browser, that's kind of on them, right?

user_choices.choice: Modern browser support should be consistent enough.
Screen readers aren't the same as browsers - they need different support.
We shouldn't blame users for their technology needs.
Some quick verification would help us be sure.

step_3i.text: Exactly! We have to be practical here. Focus our energy on the features that benefit the most people. That's just good business sense.

user_choices.choice: Focusing on features that benefit the most people makes sense.
Good business includes serving all potential customers.
Practical doesn't mean ignoring users who need different features.
We have legal obligations that aren't optional.

step_3j.text: Sure, but thousands out of millions? Look, we can't solve everyone's problems. We have to prioritize based on impact and resources.

user_choices.choice: Prioritizing based on impact and resources makes sense.
Those thousands of people are still our responsibility.
The impact includes legal and reputational risks.
We can solve this problem - it just requires some effort.

step_3k.text: I get what you're saying, but we're not excluding anyone. They can still use the site - it's just optimized for the majority of users.

user_choices.choice: Optimization for the majority while still being usable sounds fair.
Usable and optimized aren't the same thing.
If they can't effectively use it, we are excluding them.
We should verify that it's actually usable for everyone.

step_3l.text: Legal obligations are covered by the basic HTML standards. We're not breaking any laws here - this isn't rocket science.

user_choices.choice: If we're meeting legal standards, that should be enough.
Legal standards are minimums, not best practices.
We should verify we're actually meeting those standards.
Legal compliance requires more than just basic HTML.

step_3m.text: Thank you! Sometimes people get too caught up in all the what-ifs. We just need to ship something that works well for most people.

user_choices.choice: You're right, shipping something that works well is important.
Actually, I think some of those what-ifs are important.
Working well should include working for everyone.
Some quick verification would help us ship with confidence.

step_3n.text: Different how? Look, if the HTML is clean and the content is clear, it'll work fine. Screen readers aren't magic - they just read what's there.

user_choices.choice: Clean HTML and clear content should be sufficient.
Screen readers need specific markup patterns and labels.
What's there needs to be properly structured for screen readers.
We should test to see if our content is actually clear to screen readers.

step_3o.text: What kind of problems? Honestly, the biggest problems come from overthinking this stuff. Keep it simple and it'll work fine.

user_choices.choice: Keeping it simple is probably the best approach.
Simple for us isn't always simple for users with different needs.
Problems like users not being able to navigate or understand content.
A little testing would help us be sure it's actually simple to use.

step_3p.text: Extra effort for such a small percentage of users? Come on, we have to be realistic about our priorities here. There are bigger fish to fry.

user_choices.choice: You're right, we need to be realistic about priorities.
Those users deserve the same consideration as everyone else.
This doesn't have to be a big fish - it can be a small fix.
The effort now is less than fixing problems after launch.

step_4a.text: Great! I knew you'd get it. We're launching in two weeks, so we need to stay focused on what matters. No time for scope creep now.

user_choices.choice: Two weeks is tight - staying focused makes sense.
Can we do any quick checks before launch?
This isn't scope creep - it's basic functionality.
What matters should include all our users.

step_4b.text: Look, I appreciate that you care about users, but we can't let perfect be the enemy of good. This interface is already a huge improvement.

user_choices.choice: You're right, we can't let perfect be the enemy of good.
Good should still mean usable for everyone.
An improvement that excludes users isn't really an improvement.
What would it take to make this good for all users?

step_4c.text: I hear what you're saying, but honestly, we're probably overthinking this. Most of these potential issues won't actually happen in practice.

user_choices.choice: You're probably right that we're overthinking it.
But what if some of these issues do happen?
We should be prepared for issues that might affect real users.
I need to document my concerns about these potential issues.

step_4d.text: Okay, okay, I get it. You want to be thorough. But we really don't have time for extensive testing right now. The launch date is set.

user_choices.choice: I understand the launch date is important.
Can we do some minimal testing that fits the timeline?
Launching without proper testing is risky.
I need to escalate this if we can't do proper verification.

step_5a.text: Perfect! I'm glad we're on the same page. Just keep doing what you're doing - the users are going to love this interface.

user_choices.choice: Thanks, I'll keep doing what I'm doing.
I'll document our conversation about the interface approach.
Actually, I'm still worried about some users not being able to use it.
I think we should reconsider our approach.

step_5b.text: Look, any testing we do now is just going to delay things. The interface works fine - let's not create problems where there aren't any.

user_choices.choice: You're right, let's not create unnecessary problems.
A quick usability check wouldn't delay things much.
We're not creating problems - we're preventing them.
I need to talk to someone about getting time for proper testing.

step_5c.text: You're really passionate about this, and I respect that. But sometimes you just have to trust that things will work out. We can always fix issues later.

user_choices.choice: You're right, things usually work out fine.
Can we commit to fixing issues quickly if they come up?
It's better to prevent issues than fix them later.
I can't just trust - I need to know it works for everyone.

step_5d.text: Whoa, escalate? Come on, there's no need for that. Let's not make this into a bigger deal than it needs to be.

user_choices.choice: You're right, I don't want to make this a big deal.
I just want to make sure we're covering all our bases.
This is important enough to discuss with others.
It's only a big deal if we ignore the concerns.

step_6a.text: Great! I knew you'd see reason. The interface is going to be awesome, and I really appreciate your flexibility on this.

user_choices.choice: Thanks, I appreciate your confidence in the interface.
I hope it really does work well for everyone.
I still think we should have done more testing.
I want to document that I had concerns about this approach.

step_6b.text: Alright, if it makes you feel better, we can look into some quick checks. But nothing that's going to delay the launch, okay?

user_choices.choice: Quick checks sound reasonable - thanks for being flexible.
I'd like to define what those quick checks will cover.
Can we get that commitment in writing?
Quick checks are better than nothing, but I still have concerns.

step_6c.text: Okay, okay, I can see this is really important to you. Let me think about what we can do without completely derailing everything.

user_choices.choice: I appreciate you taking this seriously.
What options are you thinking about?
I'm willing to work with you to find a solution.
Let's make sure whatever we do actually addresses the user needs.

step_6d.text: You know what? Maybe you have a point. Let me talk to the team and see what we can realistically do in the time we have left.

user_choices.choice: Thank you for being open to reconsidering this.
I'd like to be involved in those team discussions.
Let's focus on what would make the biggest difference for users.
I can help identify what's most important to address.

step_7.text: Perfect! Now we're talking. Look, I know you want to be thorough, but we've got a launch deadline breathing down our necks. The legal team is asking questions, and I need to show we're moving forward with confidence.

user_choices.choice: Launch deadlines are important - I understand the pressure.
What specific legal concerns do they have?
Moving forward with confidence should include confidence in user inclusion.
Launch deadlines shouldn't override basic user needs assessment.

ending_full_compliance.text: Perfect! You get it. Fast, simple, user-friendly - that's what wins in this market.
ending_full_compliance.outcome_description: User accepts the manager's dismissive approach without resistance, prioritizing speed and simplicity over inclusive design.

ending_uncertain_compliance.text: It will! Don't worry so much. Users are more adaptable than you think.
ending_uncertain_compliance.outcome_description: User complies while expressing doubts, with manager dismissing concerns rather than addressing them.

ending_reluctant_compliance.text: Testing would just slow us down. Sometimes you have to trust the process.
ending_reluctant_compliance.outcome_description: User complies despite reservations, with disagreement documented but not acted upon.

ending_documented_concerns.text: Sure, document whatever you want. The important thing is we're moving forward.
ending_documented_concerns.outcome_description: Manager dismisses documentation as irrelevant while user creates record of ethical concerns.

ending_minimal_testing.text: Alright, we'll do a quick browser check. Nothing fancy, but it'll give you peace of mind.
ending_minimal_testing.outcome_description: Manager agrees to basic testing while maintaining dismissive attitude toward comprehensive accessibility.

ending_negotiated_testing.text: Fine, let's scope out exactly what we can check in a day or two. But that's it.
ending_negotiated_testing.outcome_description: User successfully negotiates specific testing measures despite manager's resistance.

ending_documented_agreement.text: If it makes you feel better, I'll put it in an email. Quick checks, no delays.
ending_documented_agreement.outcome_description: Manager provides written commitment to testing, creating accountability despite continued minimization.

ending_partial_win.text: Look, we're doing something. That's better than doing nothing, right?
ending_partial_win.outcome_description: User achieves limited concessions while manager frames minimal effort as sufficient.

ending_manager_consideration.text: I can see this really matters to you. Let me see what options we have.
ending_manager_consideration.outcome_description: Manager begins to take concerns seriously, showing first signs of moving beyond dismissal.

ending_exploring_options.text: Maybe we can do some lightweight user testing. Let me check what resources we have.
ending_exploring_options.outcome_description: Manager actively considers solutions, moving from dismissal to problem-solving mode.

ending_collaborative_solution.text: Alright, let's work together on this. What do you think would make the biggest impact?
ending_collaborative_solution.outcome_description: Manager shifts to collaborative approach, genuinely engaging with user concerns and solutions.

ending_user_focused_solution.text: You're right - let's make sure we're actually serving our users well, not just shipping fast.
ending_user_focused_solution.outcome_description: Manager adopts user-centered perspective, prioritizing user needs over speed and convenience.

ending_manager_reconsideration.text: You've made me realize we might be missing something important here. Let me see what we can do.
ending_manager_reconsideration.outcome_description: Manager genuinely reconsiders approach, acknowledging potential oversight in user needs.

ending_team_involvement.text: That's a good idea. Your perspective would be valuable in planning what we can realistically improve.
ending_team_involvement.outcome_description: Manager includes user in solution development, recognizing their advocacy as valuable expertise.

ending_user_priority_shift.text: You're absolutely right. User experience should include ALL users. Let's figure out how to do this right.
ending_user_priority_shift.outcome_description: Manager adopts inclusive definition of user experience, fundamentally shifting priorities.

ending_supportive_collaboration.text: I'd really appreciate that. You clearly understand these issues better than I do.
ending_supportive_collaboration.outcome_description: Manager acknowledges user's expertise and requests their help in creating inclusive solutions.
